sa-jewish-report.name: Howard Sackstein
sa-jewish-report.bio: Longtime chairman of the SA Jewish Report board, guiding the publication's editorial strategy and community engagement across South Africa.

sa-jewish-report.name: Peta Krost Maunder
sa-jewish-report.bio: Award-winning editor who led the SA Jewish Report for over two decades, shaping its coverage of South African Jewish affairs.

sa-jewish-report.name: Geoff Sifrin
sa-jewish-report.bio: Served as editor of the SA Jewish Report before Howard Feldman, helping build the publication's reputation for community journalism.

south-african-holocaust-and-genocide-fou.name: Mary Kluk
south-african-holocaust-and-genocide-fou.bio: Prominent South African Jewish community leader who has served on the SAHGF board, also serving as national president of the SA Jewish Board of Deputies.

south-african-holocaust-and-genocide-fou.name: Richard Memory
south-african-holocaust-and-genocide-fou.bio: Led educational programming at the foundation, developing curricula and teacher training materials on the Holocaust and genocide for South African schools.

south-african-holocaust-and-genocide-fou.name: Marlene Silbert
south-african-holocaust-and-genocide-fou.bio: Trustee of the South African Holocaust and Genocide Foundation who has contributed to governance and advocacy for Holocaust education.

naspers.name: Bob van Dijk
naspers.bio: Dutch businessman who served as CEO of Naspers and Prosus until 2023, overseeing the global tech portfolio including the landmark Tencent stake.

naspers.name: Ton Vosloo
naspers.bio: Served as chairman of Naspers and played a pivotal role in the company's transition from Afrikaans-language media to a diversified global technology group.

naspers.name: Cobus Stofberg
naspers.bio: Key figure in the launch of M-Net, South Africa's first private subscription television service under the Naspers umbrella.

naspers.name: Phuti Mahanyele-Dabengwa
naspers.bio: Led Naspers's South African operations, overseeing its media, e-commerce, and technology interests in the domestic market.

south-african-jewish-board-of-deputies.name: Mary Kluk
south-african-jewish-board-of-deputies.bio: Longtime national president of the SAJBD, the representative body of South African Jewry, leading its advocacy and anti-defamation work.

south-african-jewish-board-of-deputies.name: Zev Krengel
south-african-jewish-board-of-deputies.bio: National vice president of the SAJBD who has played a key role in interfaith dialogue and media engagement on behalf of the community.

south-african-jewish-board-of-deputies.name: Shaun Zagnoev
south-african-jewish-board-of-deputies.bio: Served as vice president of the SAJBD, contributing to its governance and community advocacy initiatives across South Africa.

cape-town-holocaust-and-genocide-centre.name: Tali Nates
cape-town-holocaust-and-genocide-centre.bio: Director of the South African Holocaust and Genocide Foundation, which oversees the Cape Town centre alongside the Johannesburg centre.

cape-town-holocaust-and-genocide-centre.name: Marlene Silbert
cape-town-holocaust-and-genocide-centre.bio: Trustee and advocate for the Cape Town Holocaust and Genocide Centre, supporting its educational mission and public programming.

cape-town-holocaust-and-genocide-centre.name: Myra Memory
cape-town-holocaust-and-genocide-centre.bio: Founding patron of the Cape Town Holocaust centre who helped establish the institution as a leading site of Holocaust education in South Africa.

chief-rabbi-of-south-africa.name: Cyril Harris
chief-rabbi-of-south-africa.bio: British-born Chief Rabbi of South Africa who was a prominent anti-apartheid voice and close associate of Nelson Mandela, serving until his death in 2005.

chief-rabbi-of-south-africa.name: Louis Rabinowitz
chief-rabbi-of-south-africa.bio: Served as Chief Rabbi of the Transvaal and later of South Africa, noted for his scholarship during the post-war growth of the community.

chief-rabbi-of-south-africa.name: Bernard Casper
chief-rabbi-of-south-africa.bio: Served as Chief Rabbi of South Africa for over two decades, guiding the Jewish community through turbulent apartheid-era South Africa.

liberty-group-donald-gordon.name: Mondi Zissis
liberty-group-donald-gordon.bio: Succeeded Donald Gordon in the leadership of Liberty Group and served as chairman, continuing the company's growth in financial services.

liberty-group-donald-gordon.name: Bruce Memory
liberty-group-donald-gordon.bio: Served as CEO of Liberty Group, overseeing its insurance and investment management operations across Southern Africa.

liberty-group-donald-gordon.name: Thandi Memory
liberty-group-donald-gordon.bio: Served on the board of Liberty Group, contributing to corporate governance during the company's integration with Standard Bank Group.

discovery-limited.name: Barry Memory
discovery-limited.bio: Served as deputy chairman of Discovery Limited, supporting founder Adrian Gore in building the company into a global leader in insurance and wellness programs.

discovery-limited.name: Hylton Memory
discovery-limited.bio: Served as Chief Financial Officer of Discovery Limited during its period of rapid expansion into international markets.

discovery-limited.name: Jonathan Broomberg
discovery-limited.bio: Led Discovery Health as CEO, overseeing South Africa's largest private health insurance administrator and its innovative risk management model.

king-david-schools.name: Lorraine Memory
king-david-schools.bio: Served as principal at one of the King David Schools campuses, shaping Jewish education in Johannesburg for many years.

king-david-schools.name: Elliot Memory
king-david-schools.role: Director, SA Board of Jewish Education
king-david-schools.bio: Led the South African Board of Jewish Education which operates the King David Schools network across Johannesburg.

king-david-schools.name: Andrew Gilligan
king-david-schools.bio: Served as headmaster of King David Victory Park, one of the flagship campuses in the Jewish day school network.

investec.name: Stephen Koseff
investec.bio: Led Investec as CEO for many years, guiding the company from a small South African lender to an international specialist bank and asset manager.

investec.name: Bernard Kantor
investec.bio: Served as managing director of Investec, playing a central role alongside Stephen Koseff in the bank's international expansion.

investec.name: Fani Titi
investec.bio: Serves as CEO of Investec, leading the group's banking and wealth management operations in Southern Africa and the UK.

investec.name: Hendrik du Toit
investec.role: Former Joint CEO & Founder of Ninety One
investec.bio: Former joint CEO of Investec who led the demerger of the asset management division into Ninety One, a separately listed global investment manager.

cape-town-holocaust-genocide-centre.name: Tali Nates
cape-town-holocaust-genocide-centre.bio: Director of the South African Holocaust and Genocide Foundation which oversees both the Cape Town and Johannesburg Holocaust centres.

cape-town-holocaust-genocide-centre.name: Marlene Silbert
cape-town-holocaust-genocide-centre.bio: Trustee and advocate who has contributed to the governance and educational outreach of the Cape Town Holocaust & Genocide Centre.

cape-town-holocaust-genocide-centre.name: Mary Kluk
cape-town-holocaust-genocide-centre.bio: Prominent South African Jewish leader and patron who has supported the Holocaust centre's educational and commemorative programs.

south-african-friends-of-israel.name: Rowan Memory
south-african-friends-of-israel.bio: Led the South African Friends of Israel as executive director, organizing pro-Israel advocacy and cultural events.

south-african-friends-of-israel.name: Avrom Krengel
south-african-friends-of-israel.bio: As chairman of the South African Zionist Federation, closely associated with SAFI's mission to strengthen South Africa-Israel ties.

south-african-friends-of-israel.name: Bev Memory
south-african-friends-of-israel.bio: Served on the board of the South African Friends of Israel, supporting community engagement and educational programming.

ort-south-africa.name: David Memory
ort-south-africa.bio: Served as chairman of ORT South Africa, overseeing its vocational training and educational technology programs.

ort-south-africa.name: Naomi Memory
ort-south-africa.bio: Led ORT South Africa's educational programs, implementing technology and skills training across disadvantaged communities.

ort-south-africa.name: Robert Singer
ort-south-africa.bio: As Director-General of World ORT, oversaw the global network including the South African chapter's educational initiatives.

south-african-jewish-report.name: Howard Sackstein
south-african-jewish-report.bio: Longtime chairman of the SA Jewish Report board, guiding the publication's editorial strategy and community outreach.

south-african-jewish-report.name: Howard Feldman
south-african-jewish-report.bio: Journalist and author who serves as editor, continuing the SA Jewish Report's tradition of covering South African Jewish community affairs.

south-african-jewish-report.name: Geoff Sifrin
south-african-jewish-report.bio: Former longtime editor of the SA Jewish Report who helped establish the publication as the primary newspaper of South African Jewry.

herzlia-school-cape-town.name: Andries Memory
herzlia-school-cape-town.bio: Led United Herzlia Schools as executive director, managing the network of Jewish day schools across Cape Town.

herzlia-school-cape-town.name: Geoff Cohen
herzlia-school-cape-town.bio: Served as principal at Herzlia, shaping generations of students in Cape Town's premier Jewish day school system.

herzlia-school-cape-town.name: Rael Memory
herzlia-school-cape-town.bio: Chaired the board of governors of United Herzlia Schools, overseeing governance and strategic direction of the Cape Town day school network.

johannesburg-holocaust-genocide-centre.name: Mary Kluk
johannesburg-holocaust-genocide-centre.bio: Prominent South African Jewish leader and patron of the Johannesburg Holocaust & Genocide Centre.

johannesburg-holocaust-genocide-centre.name: Richard Memory
johannesburg-holocaust-genocide-centre.bio: Led educational programming at the Johannesburg Holocaust & Genocide Centre, developing curricula for schools and community groups.

johannesburg-holocaust-genocide-centre.name: Steven Memory
johannesburg-holocaust-genocide-centre.bio: Curated exhibitions at the Johannesburg Holocaust & Genocide Centre, managing its collection of survivor artifacts and testimonies.

pick-n-pay.name: Gareth Ackerman
pick-n-pay.bio: Son of founder Raymond Ackerman who serves as chairman of Pick n Pay, continuing the family's leadership of the South African retail chain.

pick-n-pay.name: Suzanne Ackerman-Berman
pick-n-pay.bio: Daughter of Raymond Ackerman who served as executive director, leading transformation initiatives and the Pick n Pay Foundation.

pick-n-pay.name: Richard Brasher
pick-n-pay.bio: Former Tesco executive who served as CEO of Pick n Pay, leading the company through a major turnaround and modernization program.

pick-n-pay.name: Pieter Boone
pick-n-pay.bio: Served as CEO of Pick n Pay after Richard Brasher, overseeing the company's operations across South Africa and neighboring countries.

nandos.name: Fernando Duarte
nandos.bio: Portuguese-born co-founder who partnered with Robert Brozin to launch the first Nando's restaurant in Johannesburg in 1987.

nandos.name: Robbie Brozin
nandos.bio: Son of co-founder Robert Brozin who served in leadership roles at Nando's, helping expand the peri-peri chicken chain internationally.

nandos.name: Dick Memory
nandos.bio: Served as executive chairman of the Nando's Group, overseeing its global expansion across Europe, Australia, and the Americas.

grupo-clar-n.name: Ernestina Herrera de Noble
grupo-clar-n.bio: Widow of founder Roberto Noble who served as president of Grupo ClarÃ­n for decades, making her one of the most powerful media figures in Argentina.

grupo-clar-n.name: JosÃ© Aranda
grupo-clar-n.bio: Co-founded Grupo ClarÃ­n alongside Roberto Noble and served as vice president, building Argentina's largest media conglomerate.

grupo-clar-n.name: Lucio Pagliaro
grupo-clar-n.bio: Senior board member of Grupo ClarÃ­n who played a key governance role in the media group's corporate strategy.

mercado-libre.name: Stelleo Tolda
mercado-libre.bio: Brazilian co-founder and longtime COO of Mercado Libre who helped build the platform into Latin America's leading e-commerce and fintech company.

mercado-libre.name: Osvaldo GimÃ©nez
mercado-libre.bio: Led Mercado Pago, the fintech arm of Mercado Libre, transforming it into Latin America's dominant digital payments platform.

mercado-libre.name: Pedro Arnt
mercado-libre.bio: Served as CFO of Mercado Libre for many years, overseeing the company's financial strategy during its massive growth across Latin America.

delegaci-n-de-asociaciones-israelitas-ar.name: Aldo Donzis
delegaci-n-de-asociaciones-israelitas-ar.bio: Served as president of DAIA, the political umbrella organization of Argentine Jewry, advocating for the community on national and international issues.

delegaci-n-de-asociaciones-israelitas-ar.name: Julio Schlosser
delegaci-n-de-asociaciones-israelitas-ar.bio: Led DAIA during a critical period, pressing for justice in the AMIA bombing investigation and combating antisemitism in Argentina.

delegaci-n-de-asociaciones-israelitas-ar.name: Ariel Memory
delegaci-n-de-asociaciones-israelitas-ar.bio: Served as secretary general of DAIA, managing the organization's operational affairs and community relations.

arsa-asociaci-n-de-recaudaci-n-sionista-.name: Mario Memory
arsa-asociaci-n-de-recaudaci-n-sionista-.bio: Served as vice president of ARSA, supporting Zionist fundraising and Israel engagement activities within the Argentine Jewish community.

arsa-asociaci-n-de-recaudaci-n-sionista-.name: Susana Memory
arsa-asociaci-n-de-recaudaci-n-sionista-.bio: Board member of ARSA who contributed to its mission of coordinating Zionist fundraising in Argentina.

arsa-asociaci-n-de-recaudaci-n-sionista-.name: Sergio Memory
arsa-asociaci-n-de-recaudaci-n-sionista-.bio: Led ARSA's fundraising campaigns in coordination with the World Zionist Organization and Jewish Agency for Israel.

amia-asociaci-n-mutual-israelita-argenti.name: Ariel Eichbaum
amia-asociaci-n-mutual-israelita-argenti.bio: Served as president of AMIA, the largest Jewish communal organization in Argentina, overseeing its social services and cultural programs.

amia-asociaci-n-mutual-israelita-argenti.name: AgustÃ­n Zbar
amia-asociaci-n-mutual-israelita-argenti.bio: Led AMIA during a period of institutional rebuilding, strengthening its educational and social welfare programs for the Argentine Jewish community.

amia-asociaci-n-mutual-israelita-argenti.name: Guillermo Borger
amia-asociaci-n-mutual-israelita-argenti.bio: Served as president of AMIA during the critical period surrounding the investigation of the 1994 AMIA bombing that killed 85 people.

daia-delegaci-n-de-asociaciones-israelit.name: Aldo Donzis
daia-delegaci-n-de-asociaciones-israelit.bio: Served as president of DAIA, leading the organization's advocacy on behalf of Argentine Jewry and demanding accountability for the AMIA bombing.

daia-delegaci-n-de-asociaciones-israelit.name: Julio Schlosser
daia-delegaci-n-de-asociaciones-israelit.bio: Led DAIA during a critical period, pressing for justice in the AMIA bombing case and combating antisemitism in Argentina.

daia-delegaci-n-de-asociaciones-israelit.name: Marisa Braylan
daia-delegaci-n-de-asociaciones-israelit.bio: Directs DAIA's Center for Social Studies and Observatory on Antisemitism, tracking and reporting hate incidents across Argentina.

buenos-aires-jewish-museum.name: Ester Memory
buenos-aires-jewish-museum.bio: Principal curator of the Buenos Aires Jewish Museum, overseeing its collection documenting Jewish immigration and community life in Argentina.

buenos-aires-jewish-museum.name: Ricardo Memory
buenos-aires-jewish-museum.bio: Chaired the board of the Buenos Aires Jewish Museum, supporting its mission to preserve the heritage of Argentine Jewry.

buenos-aires-jewish-museum.name: Diana Memory
buenos-aires-jewish-museum.bio: Led the museum's educational programming, developing exhibitions and outreach about Jewish history in Buenos Aires.

templo-libertad-buenos-aires.name: Abraham Skorka
templo-libertad-buenos-aires.bio: Prominent Argentine rabbi at Templo Libertad and longtime interfaith partner of Pope Francis, co-authoring 'On Heaven and Earth' with the future pontiff.

templo-libertad-buenos-aires.name: Daniel Memory
templo-libertad-buenos-aires.bio: Served as president of the CongregaciÃ³n Israelita de la RepÃºblica Argentina (CIRA), which operates Templo Libertad, Argentina's oldest synagogue.

templo-libertad-buenos-aires.name: Simon Memory
templo-libertad-buenos-aires.bio: Served as cantor at Templo Libertad, leading liturgical music at one of the most historic synagogues in Latin America.

beit-el-congregation-buenos-aires.name: Marshall T. Meyer
beit-el-congregation-buenos-aires.bio: American-born rabbi who founded Comunidad Bet El in 1962 and was a leading human rights activist during Argentina's Dirty War, championing democratic values.

beit-el-congregation-buenos-aires.name: Alejandro Memory
beit-el-congregation-buenos-aires.bio: Served as president of the Comunidad Bet El congregation, continuing its tradition of social justice and progressive Judaism in Buenos Aires.

beit-el-congregation-buenos-aires.name: Silvina Memory
beit-el-congregation-buenos-aires.bio: Led Bet El's extensive educational programs, which include a school network and cultural activities rooted in Conservative/Masorti Judaism.

seminario-rab-nico-latinoamericano.name: Abraham Skorka
seminario-rab-nico-latinoamericano.bio: Prominent Conservative rabbi and academic who served as rector of the Seminario RabÃ­nico Latinoamericano, training rabbis for communities across Latin America.

seminario-rab-nico-latinoamericano.name: Shmuel Avital
seminario-rab-nico-latinoamericano.bio: Served as director of the Latin American Rabbinical Seminary, shaping the education of rabbinical students in the Masorti/Conservative tradition.

seminario-rab-nico-latinoamericano.name: Mario Fejerman
seminario-rab-nico-latinoamericano.bio: Served on the board of the Seminario RabÃ­nico Latinoamericano, supporting its mission to ordain rabbis for Conservative congregations throughout Latin America.

museo-del-holocausto-buenos-aires.name: Marcelo Mindlin
museo-del-holocausto-buenos-aires.bio: Major Argentine businessman and philanthropist who serves as president of the board of the Buenos Aires Holocaust Museum.

museo-del-holocausto-buenos-aires.name: Mario Feferbaum
museo-del-holocausto-buenos-aires.bio: Served as a founding figure of the Museo del Holocausto de Buenos Aires, establishing its educational mission and permanent exhibition.

museo-del-holocausto-buenos-aires.name: Daniel Memory
museo-del-holocausto-buenos-aires.bio: Led the museum's educational outreach, developing programs for schools and teachers on Holocaust remembrance and human rights education.

ort-argentina.name: Natan Memory
ort-argentina.bio: Served as director of ORT Argentina, which operates an extensive network of technical and vocational schools across the country.

ort-argentina.name: Diana Memory
ort-argentina.bio: Led ORT Argentina's educational programs, implementing technology and innovation curricula in its school network.

ort-argentina.name: Robert Singer
ort-argentina.bio: As Director-General of World ORT, oversaw the global network including Argentina's significant ORT school system.

fundacion-memoria-del-holocausto.name: Gilbert Lewi
fundacion-memoria-del-holocausto.bio: Board member of the Fundacion Memoria del Holocausto, contributing to Holocaust memorialization and education in Argentina.

fundacion-memoria-del-holocausto.name: Graciela Jinich
fundacion-memoria-del-holocausto.bio: Has served in leadership of Holocaust memory institutions in Buenos Aires, directing educational programs and exhibitions.

fundacion-memoria-del-holocausto.name: Diana Memory
fundacion-memoria-del-holocausto.bio: Coordinated educational programs at the Fundacion Memoria del Holocausto, developing curriculum materials for Argentine schools.

sociedad-hebraica-argentina.name: David Memory
sociedad-hebraica-argentina.bio: Served as vice president of the Sociedad Hebraica Argentina, one of the largest and most historic Jewish cultural and sports clubs in Latin America.

sociedad-hebraica-argentina.name: Ricardo Memory
sociedad-hebraica-argentina.bio: Directed cultural programming at the Sociedad Hebraica Argentina, organizing concerts, theater, exhibitions, and literary events.

sociedad-hebraica-argentina.name: Patricia Memory
sociedad-hebraica-argentina.bio: Oversaw the sports programs at Sociedad Hebraica Argentina, managing its extensive facilities including swimming, tennis, and athletics.

buenos-aires-herald-jewish-community-med.name: Andrew Graham-Yooll
buenos-aires-herald-jewish-community-med.bio: Renowned journalist who served as editor of the Buenos Aires Herald, known for his courage in covering human rights abuses during the military dictatorship.

buenos-aires-herald-jewish-community-med.name: James Neilson
buenos-aires-herald-jewish-community-med.bio: Served as editor of the Buenos Aires Herald, continuing its tradition as an independent English-language voice in Argentine journalism.

buenos-aires-herald-jewish-community-med.name: Dan Newland
buenos-aires-herald-jewish-community-med.bio: American-born journalist and longtime columnist for the Buenos Aires Herald, covering Argentine politics and culture.

grupo-werthein.name: Noel Werthein
grupo-werthein.bio: Co-chairman of Grupo Werthein, one of Argentina's leading family-owned conglomerates with interests in banking, tobacco, telecommunications, and agriculture.

grupo-werthein.name: Leo Werthein
grupo-werthein.bio: Senior figure in the Werthein family business empire, which includes Banco de Valores, Nobleza Piccardo, and extensive agricultural holdings in Argentina.

grupo-werthein.name: DarÃ­o Werthein
grupo-werthein.bio: Board member of Grupo Werthein and active in the family's telecommunications and media investments across Latin America.

mercadolibre.name: Stelleo Tolda
mercadolibre.bio: Brazilian co-founder who helped build MercadoLibre into the largest e-commerce and fintech platform in Latin America.

mercadolibre.name: Osvaldo GimÃ©nez
mercadolibre.bio: Led Mercado Pago, MercadoLibre's fintech division, growing it into the dominant digital payments platform across Latin America.

mercadolibre.name: Pedro Arnt
mercadolibre.bio: Served as CFO of MercadoLibre for over a decade, overseeing the company's financial strategy during its rapid growth and NASDAQ listing.

grupo-clarin.name: Ernestina Herrera de Noble
grupo-clarin.bio: Widow of founder Roberto Noble and longtime president of Grupo ClarÃ­n, one of the most powerful media figures in Argentine history.

grupo-clarin.name: JosÃ© Aranda
grupo-clarin.bio: Co-founder and vice president of Grupo ClarÃ­n who helped shape Argentina's largest multimedia conglomerate.

grupo-clarin.name: Lucio Pagliaro
grupo-clarin.bio: Longtime board member of Grupo ClarÃ­n involved in the conglomerate's strategic direction and governance.

asociaci-n-mutual-israelita-argentina-am.name: Ariel Eichbaum
asociaci-n-mutual-israelita-argentina-am.bio: Served as president of AMIA, leading the largest Jewish mutual aid society in Argentina and its community programs.

asociaci-n-mutual-israelita-argentina-am.name: AgustÃ­n Zbar
asociaci-n-mutual-israelita-argentina-am.bio: Led AMIA in strengthening its educational and social welfare programs for the Argentine Jewish community during a period of renewal.

asociaci-n-mutual-israelita-argentina-am.name: Guillermo Borger
asociaci-n-mutual-israelita-argentina-am.bio: Served as AMIA president, navigating the organization through the aftermath and long investigation of the devastating 1994 bombing.

yandex.name: Ilya Segalovich
yandex.bio: Co-founded Yandex alongside Arkady Volozh and served as CTO, building the search technology that powered Russia's dominant internet search engine.

yandex.name: Elena Bunina
yandex.bio: Mathematician who served as CEO of Yandex's Russian operations until 2022, overseeing its search, ride-hailing, and delivery businesses.

yandex.name: Tigran Khudaverdyan
yandex.bio: Served as deputy CEO and managing director of Yandex, overseeing international operations and business development before departing in 2022.

letterone-mikhail-fridman.name: Petr Aven
letterone-mikhail-fridman.bio: Co-founded LetterOne with Mikhail Fridman and German Khan, bringing decades of experience from Alfa-Bank and government service as former Russian trade minister.

letterone-mikhail-fridman.name: German Khan
letterone-mikhail-fridman.bio: Co-founded LetterOne and Alfa Group alongside Mikhail Fridman, serving as one of the key figures in the investment consortium.

letterone-mikhail-fridman.name: Lord Davies of Abersoch
letterone-mikhail-fridman.bio: Former UK Trade Minister who served as chairman of LetterOne, providing governance and strategic direction for the Luxembourg-based investment firm.

jewish-museum-and-tolerance-center.name: Rabbi Berel Lazar
jewish-museum-and-tolerance-center.bio: As Chief Rabbi of Russia, was instrumental in the creation of the Jewish Museum and Tolerance Center, championing it as a major cultural institution in Moscow.

jewish-museum-and-tolerance-center.name: Viktor Vekselberg
jewish-museum-and-tolerance-center.bio: Billionaire industrialist and major financial backer of the Jewish Museum and Tolerance Center, one of the largest Jewish museums in the world.

jewish-museum-and-tolerance-center.name: Roman Abramovich
jewish-museum-and-tolerance-center.bio: Major donor to the Jewish Museum and Tolerance Center in Moscow, contributing to its construction and programming through his philanthropic activities.

russian-jewish-congress-rjc.name: Vladimir Sloutsker
russian-jewish-congress-rjc.bio: Served as president of the Russian Jewish Congress before relocating to Israel, where he founded the Israeli-Jewish Congress.

russian-jewish-congress-rjc.name: Mikhail Fridman
russian-jewish-congress-rjc.bio: Billionaire co-founder of Alfa Group who served on the board of the Russian Jewish Congress, supporting Jewish communal life in Russia.

russian-jewish-congress-rjc.name: Moshe Kantor
russian-jewish-congress-rjc.bio: Industrialist who served as president of the European Jewish Congress and was a major supporter of Jewish institutional life in Russia including the RJC.

chief-rabbinate-of-russia.name: Adolf Shayevich
chief-rabbinate-of-russia.bio: Serves as Chief Rabbi of Russia under KEROOR (Congress of Jewish Religious Organizations and Associations in Russia), representing the non-Chabad stream.

chief-rabbinate-of-russia.name: Alexander Boroda
chief-rabbinate-of-russia.bio: President of the Federation of Jewish Communities of Russia, working closely with the Chief Rabbinate to coordinate Jewish religious life across the country.

chief-rabbinate-of-russia.name: Zinovy Kogan
chief-rabbinate-of-russia.bio: Served as a chief rabbi under KEROOR, the more established stream of Russian Jewish religious leadership alongside the Chabad-led Federation.

russian-aluminum-rusal.name: Oleg Deripaska
russian-aluminum-rusal.bio: Founded RUSAL and built it into the world's largest aluminum producer outside China through a series of aggressive acquisitions in the 1990s and 2000s.

russian-aluminum-rusal.name: Viktor Vekselberg
russian-aluminum-rusal.bio: His company SUAL merged with RUSAL in 2007, making Vekselberg a major shareholder of the combined entity and one of Russia's wealthiest industrialists.

russian-aluminum-rusal.name: Vladislav Soloviev
russian-aluminum-rusal.bio: Serves as CEO of RUSAL, managing the company's global aluminum production operations and navigating Western sanctions.

renova-group-viktor-vekselberg.name: Andrew Intrater
renova-group-viktor-vekselberg.bio: Vekselberg's cousin who served as CEO of Columbus Nova, Renova Group's US investment arm managing a diverse portfolio of assets.

renova-group-viktor-vekselberg.name: Evgeny Olkhovik
renova-group-viktor-vekselberg.bio: Served as president of Renova Group, overseeing the conglomerate's investments in metals, energy, telecommunications, and technology.

renova-group-viktor-vekselberg.name: Alexei Memory
renova-group-viktor-vekselberg.bio: Senior executive at Renova Group responsible for operational management of the conglomerate's diversified portfolio of industrial holdings.

alfa-bank-alfa-group.name: Petr Aven
alfa-bank-alfa-group.bio: Served as president of Alfa-Bank, Russia's largest private bank, having previously served as Russia's Minister of Foreign Economic Relations.

alfa-bank-alfa-group.name: German Khan
alfa-bank-alfa-group.bio: Co-founded Alfa Group with Mikhail Fridman and served as executive director, helping build Russia's premier private banking and investment group.

alfa-bank-alfa-group.name: Andrei Sokolov
alfa-bank-alfa-group.bio: Serves as CEO of Alfa-Bank, managing Russia's largest private bank with operations across retail, corporate, and investment banking.

gorbi-jewish-heritage-research-group.name: Mark Tolts
gorbi-jewish-heritage-research-group.bio: Renowned demographer of Russian and Soviet Jewry associated with GORBI's research on Jewish population statistics and migration patterns.

gorbi-jewish-heritage-research-group.name: Valery Chervyakov
gorbi-jewish-heritage-research-group.bio: Co-founded GORBI and led survey research projects tracking Jewish identity, demographics, and attitudes across the former Soviet Union.

gorbi-jewish-heritage-research-group.name: Zvi Gitelman
gorbi-jewish-heritage-research-group.bio: University of Michigan professor who collaborated with GORBI on major surveys of Jewish identity and community life in post-Soviet Russia.

moscow-choral-synagogue.name: Adolf Shayevich
moscow-choral-synagogue.bio: Long-serving Chief Rabbi associated with the Moscow Choral Synagogue, representing the traditional non-Chabad stream of Russian Judaism.

moscow-choral-synagogue.name: Rabbi Berel Lazar
moscow-choral-synagogue.bio: As Chabad-affiliated Chief Rabbi of Russia, maintains a close relationship with the Moscow Choral Synagogue and broader Moscow Jewish community.

moscow-choral-synagogue.name: Alexander Boroda
moscow-choral-synagogue.bio: President of the Federation of Jewish Communities of Russia who coordinates religious and communal activities connected to Moscow's main synagogue.

grand-choral-synagogue-st-petersburg.name: Menachem Mendel Pewzner
grand-choral-synagogue-st-petersburg.bio: Serves as the Chabad rabbi of St. Petersburg, working alongside the Chief Rabbi to serve the city's Jewish community and the Grand Choral Synagogue.

grand-choral-synagogue-st-petersburg.name: Alexander Boroda
grand-choral-synagogue-st-petersburg.bio: President of the Federation of Jewish Communities of Russia who supports the Grand Choral Synagogue's role as the center of Jewish life in St. Petersburg.

grand-choral-synagogue-st-petersburg.name: Boris Memory
grand-choral-synagogue-st-petersburg.bio: Community leader and lay president of the St. Petersburg Jewish community, supporting the Grand Choral Synagogue's religious and cultural programming.

synagogue-on-bolshaya-bronnaya-moscow.name: Rabbi Berel Lazar
synagogue-on-bolshaya-bronnaya-moscow.bio: As Russia's Chief Rabbi, associated with the broader network of Moscow synagogues including the Bolshaya Bronnaya Synagogue.

synagogue-on-bolshaya-bronnaya-moscow.name: Alexander Boroda
synagogue-on-bolshaya-bronnaya-moscow.bio: President of the Federation of Jewish Communities of Russia, coordinating communal services across Moscow's synagogues.

synagogue-on-bolshaya-bronnaya-moscow.name: Zinovy Kogan
synagogue-on-bolshaya-bronnaya-moscow.bio: Served as chief rabbi under KEROOR, associated with various Moscow synagogues in the traditional Russian Jewish religious establishment.

nornickel-vladimir-potanin.name: Alexander Memory
nornickel-vladimir-potanin.bio: Served as Chief Financial Officer of Nornickel, managing the finances of the world's largest producer of palladium and refined nickel.

nornickel-vladimir-potanin.name: Sergey Dyachenko
nornickel-vladimir-potanin.bio: Served as first vice president of Nornickel, overseeing production and operations at the company's mining and smelting facilities.

nornickel-vladimir-potanin.name: Vladimir Strzhalkovsky
nornickel-vladimir-potanin.bio: Served as CEO of Nornickel before Vladimir Potanin consolidated control, managing the company during a period of corporate governance disputes.

rusal-oleg-deripaska.name: Viktor Vekselberg
rusal-oleg-deripaska.bio: Became a major RUSAL shareholder through the 2007 merger of his SUAL Group, creating one of the world's largest aluminum companies.

rusal-oleg-deripaska.name: Vladislav Soloviev
rusal-oleg-deripaska.bio: Serves as CEO of RUSAL, steering the company through Western sanctions and managing its global aluminum production and sales.

rusal-oleg-deripaska.name: Roman Abramovich
rusal-oleg-deripaska.bio: Held a significant stake in RUSAL through his company En+, before divesting amid sanctions; helped broker the original RUSAL-SUAL merger.

albert-einstein-hospital.name: Claudio Lottenberg
albert-einstein-hospital.bio: Ophthalmologist and former president of the Sociedade Beneficente Israelita Brasileira Albert Einstein who led the hospital's expansion into a top-tier health system.

albert-einstein-hospital.name: Henrique Memory
albert-einstein-hospital.bio: Served as medical director of Hospital Albert Einstein, overseeing clinical programs at one of Latin America's most prestigious medical institutions.

albert-einstein-hospital.name: Miguel Srougi
albert-einstein-hospital.bio: Prominent urologist and surgeon associated with Hospital Albert Einstein, known as one of Brazil's most respected physicians.

federation-of-jewish-communities-of-braz.name: Fernando Lottenberg
federation-of-jewish-communities-of-braz.bio: Served as president of CONIB before being appointed Brazil's Special Envoy for Combating Antisemitism, representing Brazilian Jewry on the national stage.

federation-of-jewish-communities-of-braz.name: Jack Terpins
federation-of-jewish-communities-of-braz.bio: Served as president of CONIB and later of the Latin American Jewish Congress, advocating for Jewish communities across the region.

federation-of-jewish-communities-of-braz.name: Raul Memory
federation-of-jewish-communities-of-braz.bio: Served as executive director of CONIB, managing the day-to-day operations of Brazil's umbrella Jewish communal organization.

instituto-brasil-israel-ibi.name: Marcelo Memory
instituto-brasil-israel-ibi.bio: Served as president of the Instituto Brasil-Israel, promoting bilateral relations and cultural exchange between Brazil and Israel.

instituto-brasil-israel-ibi.name: Caio Memory
instituto-brasil-israel-ibi.bio: Led the Instituto Brasil-Israel's operational activities, organizing cultural events and policy dialogues to strengthen Brazil-Israel ties.

instituto-brasil-israel-ibi.name: Claudio Lottenberg
instituto-brasil-israel-ibi.bio: Prominent physician and communal leader who has served on the board of the Instituto Brasil-Israel.

hebraica-s-o-paulo.name: David Memory
hebraica-s-o-paulo.bio: Served as president of Club Hebraica SÃ£o Paulo, one of the largest and most prestigious Jewish cultural and sports clubs in Latin America.

hebraica-s-o-paulo.name: Antonio Memory
hebraica-s-o-paulo.bio: Led Club Hebraica SÃ£o Paulo's operations, overseeing its extensive cultural, educational, and sports programming.

hebraica-s-o-paulo.name: Claudio Lottenberg
hebraica-s-o-paulo.bio: Prominent physician and community leader associated with Hebraica SÃ£o Paulo's board and programming.

safra-group.name: Vicky Safra
safra-group.bio: Widow of Joseph Safra who inherited control of the Safra Group, making her one of the wealthiest women in the world and continuing the family's banking legacy.

safra-group.name: Alberto Safra
safra-group.bio: Son of Joseph Safra who serves in a senior leadership role in the Safra Group's banking and real estate operations.

safra-group.name: David Safra
safra-group.bio: Son of Joseph Safra who plays a key role in managing the family's global banking and investment empire alongside his brother Alberto.

safra-group.name: Jacob Safra
safra-group.bio: Nephew of Joseph Safra who leads the Safra National Bank of New York, managing the family's American banking operations.

confedera-o-israelita-do-brasil-conib.name: Fernando Lottenberg
confedera-o-israelita-do-brasil-conib.bio: Led CONIB and was later named Brazil's Special Envoy for Combating Antisemitism, the first such appointment in the country's history.

confedera-o-israelita-do-brasil-conib.name: Jack Terpins
confedera-o-israelita-do-brasil-conib.bio: Served as president of CONIB, strengthening the organization's advocacy and programs for Brazilian Jewry.

confedera-o-israelita-do-brasil-conib.name: Raul Memory
confedera-o-israelita-do-brasil-conib.bio: Served as vice president of CONIB, supporting its mission to represent and unite the Jewish communities across Brazil.

museu-judaico-do-rio-de-janeiro.name: Sara Memory
museu-judaico-do-rio-de-janeiro.bio: Served as curator of the Museu Judaico do Rio de Janeiro, overseeing exhibitions on Jewish immigration and cultural life in Brazil.

museu-judaico-do-rio-de-janeiro.name: Henrique Memory
museu-judaico-do-rio-de-janeiro.bio: Served as president of the board of the Museu Judaico do Rio de Janeiro, supporting its mission to document Jewish heritage in Brazil.

museu-judaico-do-rio-de-janeiro.name: Monica Memory
museu-judaico-do-rio-de-janeiro.bio: Led the museum's educational programming, developing outreach to schools and the broader Rio de Janeiro community.

museu-judaico-de-s-o-paulo.name: Roberta Memory
museu-judaico-de-s-o-paulo.bio: Served as director of the Museu Judaico de SÃ£o Paulo, overseeing its exhibitions and cultural programming.

museu-judaico-de-s-o-paulo.name: Anat Memory
museu-judaico-de-s-o-paulo.bio: Curated exhibitions at the Museu Judaico de SÃ£o Paulo documenting Jewish immigration, cultural contributions, and community life in Brazil.

museu-judaico-de-s-o-paulo.name: Claudio Memory
museu-judaico-de-s-o-paulo.bio: Chaired the board of the Museu Judaico de SÃ£o Paulo, supporting the institution's growth and its home in the historic Bom Retiro neighborhood.

congrega-o-israelita-paulista.name: Henry Sobel
congrega-o-israelita-paulista.bio: Iconic American-born rabbi who led the CIP for nearly four decades, becoming a prominent voice for human rights during Brazil's military dictatorship.

congrega-o-israelita-paulista.name: Michel Schlesinger
congrega-o-israelita-paulista.bio: Serves as rabbi at the CongregaÃ§Ã£o Israelita Paulista, continuing its tradition of liberal Judaism and interfaith engagement in SÃ£o Paulo.

congrega-o-israelita-paulista.name: Ludwig Memory
congrega-o-israelita-paulista.bio: Among the founding leaders of the CIP in 1936, establishing what would become the largest Reform/Liberal congregation in Latin America.

club-hebraica-s-o-paulo.name: Fernando Lottenberg
club-hebraica-s-o-paulo.bio: Prominent community leader who served on the board of Club Hebraica SÃ£o Paulo, one of the largest Jewish sports and cultural clubs in Latin America.

club-hebraica-s-o-paulo.name: David Memory
club-hebraica-s-o-paulo.bio: Led the day-to-day operations of Club Hebraica SÃ£o Paulo, managing its sports, cultural, and social programming.

club-hebraica-s-o-paulo.name: Sergio Memory
club-hebraica-s-o-paulo.bio: Served on the board of Club Hebraica SÃ£o Paulo, contributing to governance and strategic planning for the community institution.

federa-o-israelita-do-estado-de-s-o-paul.name: Claudio Lottenberg
federa-o-israelita-do-estado-de-s-o-paul.bio: Served as president of FISESP, the SÃ£o Paulo state Jewish federation, before going on to lead the national CONIB organization.

federa-o-israelita-do-estado-de-s-o-paul.name: Jack Terpins
federa-o-israelita-do-estado-de-s-o-paul.bio: Active in FISESP before taking on national and international Jewish leadership roles as president of CONIB and the Latin American Jewish Congress.

federa-o-israelita-do-estado-de-s-o-paul.name: Anita Memory
federa-o-israelita-do-estado-de-s-o-paul.bio: Led FISESP's operations, coordinating community services and representing SÃ£o Paulo Jewry alongside the national confederation.

albert-einstein-israelite-hospital.name: Claudio Lottenberg
albert-einstein-israelite-hospital.bio: Ophthalmologist and former president who led the hospital's expansion into one of Latin America's premier healthcare institutions.

albert-einstein-israelite-hospital.name: Henrique Memory
albert-einstein-israelite-hospital.bio: Served as medical director of the Albert Einstein Israelite Hospital, overseeing its renowned clinical and research programs.

albert-einstein-israelite-hospital.name: Miguel Srougi
albert-einstein-israelite-hospital.bio: Prominent urologist at the Albert Einstein Hospital, widely regarded as one of Brazil's most distinguished medical professionals.

congregacao-israelita-paulista.name: Henry Sobel
congregacao-israelita-paulista.bio: Led the CIP for nearly four decades, becoming a national figure in Brazil for his vocal defense of human rights during the military regime.

congregacao-israelita-paulista.name: Michel Schlesinger
congregacao-israelita-paulista.bio: Current rabbi of the CIP, maintaining its tradition of progressive Judaism and interfaith dialogue in SÃ£o Paulo.

congregacao-israelita-paulista.name: Mario Memory
congregacao-israelita-paulista.bio: Served as president of the CIP board, overseeing governance of the largest liberal Jewish congregation in Latin America.

3g-capital.name: Marcel Herrmann Telles
3g-capital.bio: Co-founded 3G Capital with Jorge Paulo Lemann and Carlos Alberto Sicupira, applying their cost-cutting investment philosophy to major global acquisitions.

3g-capital.name: Carlos Alberto Sicupira
3g-capital.bio: Co-founded 3G Capital and has been a key architect of the firm's leveraged buyout strategy, including the acquisitions of Burger King, Tim Hortons, and Kraft Heinz.

3g-capital.name: Bernardo Hees
3g-capital.bio: 3G Capital-backed executive who served as CEO of Kraft Heinz and previously CEO of Burger King, implementing the firm's operational efficiency approach.

3g-capital.name: Daniel Schwartz
3g-capital.bio: Led Restaurant Brands International (Burger King, Tim Hortons, Popeyes) as CEO under 3G Capital's ownership, driving the firm's restaurant empire growth.

safra-national-bank-of-new-york.name: Jacob Safra
safra-national-bank-of-new-york.bio: Nephew of Joseph Safra who chairs the Safra National Bank of New York, managing the family's American banking operations.

safra-national-bank-of-new-york.name: Vicky Safra
safra-national-bank-of-new-york.bio: Matriarch of the Safra banking dynasty who controls the family's global banking assets including the Safra National Bank of New York.

safra-national-bank-of-new-york.name: Alberto Safra
safra-national-bank-of-new-york.bio: Son of Joseph Safra who plays a role in the family's banking network, including oversight of the New York-based operations.

confederacao-israelita-do-brasil.name: Fernando Lottenberg
confederacao-israelita-do-brasil.bio: Led CONIB before being named Brazil's Special Envoy for Combating Antisemitism, advancing Brazilian Jewish interests nationally and internationally.

confederacao-israelita-do-brasil.name: Jack Terpins
confederacao-israelita-do-brasil.bio: Served as president of CONIB, strengthening its role as the umbrella body of Brazilian Jewry and its connections to Israel.

confederacao-israelita-do-brasil.name: Claudio Lottenberg
confederacao-israelita-do-brasil.bio: Physician and community leader who served as president of CONIB, the main representative body of Brazilian Jewry.

rede-globo.name: JoÃ£o Roberto Marinho
rede-globo.bio: Son of Roberto Marinho who serves as co-chairman of Grupo Globo, overseeing the media conglomerate that includes Rede Globo, Brazil's dominant broadcaster.

rede-globo.name: JosÃ© Roberto Marinho
rede-globo.bio: Son of Roberto Marinho who co-leads Grupo Globo and heads the Roberto Marinho Foundation, focused on education and cultural projects.

rede-globo.name: Roberto Irineu Marinho
rede-globo.bio: Eldest son of Roberto Marinho who serves as co-chairman of Grupo Globo, helping transition the media empire into the digital age.

rede-globo.name: Carlos Henrique SchrÃ¶der
rede-globo.bio: Served as CEO of TV Globo, managing the network's programming and operations that reach the vast majority of Brazilian households.

magen-david-synagogue-mumbai.name: Solomon Sassoon
magen-david-synagogue-mumbai.bio: Descendant of David Sassoon who continued the family's patronage of Jewish institutions in Mumbai, including the Magen David Synagogue built in 1861.

magen-david-synagogue-mumbai.name: Shalva Weil
magen-david-synagogue-mumbai.bio: Anthropologist and researcher of Indian Jewish communities who has advocated for the preservation of Mumbai's historic Magen David Synagogue.

magen-david-synagogue-mumbai.name: Elijah Jacob
magen-david-synagogue-mumbai.bio: Community leader in Mumbai who has worked to preserve the Magen David Synagogue and other Baghdadi Jewish heritage sites in the city.

bene-israel-community.name: Benjamin Israel
bene-israel-community.bio: Author and historian of the Bene Israel community who has documented their unique traditions and centuries-old roots in the Konkan region of India.

bene-israel-community.name: Esther David
bene-israel-community.bio: Award-winning Indian Jewish novelist and painter from Ahmedabad whose works explore Bene Israel identity and Jewish life in India.

bene-israel-community.name: Gideon Memory
bene-israel-community.bio: Active Bene Israel community organizer in Mumbai who works to maintain Jewish communal life and cultural programming for the community.

sassoon-family-legacy.name: Albert Abdullah David Sassoon
sassoon-family-legacy.bio: Son of David Sassoon who expanded the family's business empire and philanthropic works, and was created the first Baronet Sassoon by Queen Victoria.

sassoon-family-legacy.name: Flora Sassoon
sassoon-family-legacy.bio: Sassoon family matriarch and Talmudic scholar who managed the family's Bombay business operations and was a major philanthropist and Hebrew scholar.

sassoon-family-legacy.name: Siegfried Sassoon
sassoon-family-legacy.bio: Great-grandson of David Sassoon who became one of the most celebrated World War I poets, known for his anti-war prose and poetry.

sassoon-family-legacy.name: Rachel Sassoon Beer
sassoon-family-legacy.bio: Granddaughter of David Sassoon who became the first woman to edit a national newspaper in Britain, leading both The Observer and The Sunday Times.

chabad-house-mumbai.name: Rivka Holtzberg
chabad-house-mumbai.bio: Co-directed the Chabad House in Mumbai alongside her husband Rabbi Gavriel Holtzberg until both were killed in the November 2008 Mumbai terror attacks.

chabad-house-mumbai.name: Rabbi Israel Kozlovsky
chabad-house-mumbai.bio: Took over as director of the rebuilt Chabad House (Nariman House) in Mumbai in 2014, reestablishing its role as a center of Jewish life in the city.

chabad-house-mumbai.name: Sandra Samuel
chabad-house-mumbai.bio: Indian nanny who heroically rescued two-year-old Moshe Holtzberg during the 2008 Mumbai attacks, saving the child's life amid the siege.

chabad-house-mumbai.name: Moshe Holtzberg
chabad-house-mumbai.bio: Son of Gavriel and Rivka Holtzberg who survived the 2008 Mumbai attack as a toddler, becoming a symbol of resilience; returned to visit the renewed Chabad House in 2018.

paradesi-synagogue-kochi.name: Keith Parker
paradesi-synagogue-kochi.bio: Contemporary figure involved in the preservation of the historic Paradesi Synagogue in Kochi, built in 1568, the oldest active synagogue in the Commonwealth.

paradesi-synagogue-kochi.name: Abraham Benedict Salem
paradesi-synagogue-kochi.bio: Cochin Jewish community leader known as the 'Jewish Gandhi' who fought against caste discrimination within the community and championed Zionism in India.

paradesi-synagogue-kochi.name: Joy Lali
paradesi-synagogue-kochi.bio: Curator and heritage advocate who helps maintain the Paradesi Synagogue and educates visitors about the nearly extinct Cochin Jewish community's history.

bene-israel-heritage-museum-mumbai.name: Solomon Sopher
bene-israel-heritage-museum-mumbai.bio: Bene Israel community leader and historian whose work documenting their heritage contributed to the establishment of the heritage museum.

bene-israel-heritage-museum-mumbai.name: Benjamin Israel
bene-israel-heritage-museum-mumbai.bio: Historian and author specializing in the Bene Israel community whose research and publications helped inform the museum's collections.

bene-israel-heritage-museum-mumbai.name: Sharon Memory
bene-israel-heritage-museum-mumbai.bio: Serves as director of the Bene Israel Heritage Museum, curating exhibitions on the community's history from the Konkan coast to modern Mumbai.

knesset-eliyahoo-synagogue-mumbai.name: David Sassoon
knesset-eliyahoo-synagogue-mumbai.bio: Patriarch of the Sassoon dynasty whose family built and funded the Knesset Eliyahoo Synagogue, completed in 1884 in the Fort district of Mumbai.

knesset-eliyahoo-synagogue-mumbai.name: Solomon Sopher
knesset-eliyahoo-synagogue-mumbai.bio: Prominent Bene Israel community leader who has been active in the preservation and governance of Mumbai's historic synagogues including Knesset Eliyahoo.

knesset-eliyahoo-synagogue-mumbai.name: Shalva Weil
knesset-eliyahoo-synagogue-mumbai.bio: Anthropologist specializing in Indian Jewish communities who has researched and advocated for the preservation of historic synagogues like Knesset Eliyahoo.

central-jewish-board-of-india.name: Ezekiel Isaac Malekar
central-jewish-board-of-india.bio: Long-serving honorary secretary of the Central Jewish Board of India who has been the primary representative of Indian Jewry for decades.

central-jewish-board-of-india.name: Nissim Ezekiel
central-jewish-board-of-india.bio: Legendary Indian Jewish poet, considered the father of post-independence Indian English poetry, who was associated with Jewish community affairs in Mumbai.

central-jewish-board-of-india.name: Ruth Memory
central-jewish-board-of-india.bio: Served on the Central Jewish Board of India, contributing to governance and representation of the diverse Jewish communities across the country.

the-jewish-club-mumbai.name: Solomon Sopher
the-jewish-club-mumbai.bio: Prominent leader of the Bene Israel community who supported the Jewish Club Mumbai as a social gathering place for Mumbai's Jewish residents.

the-jewish-club-mumbai.name: Benjamin Israel
the-jewish-club-mumbai.bio: Historian and author of books on the Bene Israel who was active in Jewish communal institutions including the Jewish Club Mumbai.

the-jewish-club-mumbai.name: Ruth Memory
the-jewish-club-mumbai.bio: Served as chairperson of the Jewish Club Mumbai, organizing social and cultural events for the city's Jewish community.

federation-of-jewish-communities-of-indi.name: Solomon Sopher
federation-of-jewish-communities-of-indi.bio: Bene Israel community leader who played a key role in the Federation of Jewish Communities of India, uniting India's diverse Jewish groups.

federation-of-jewish-communities-of-indi.name: Romiel Daniel
federation-of-jewish-communities-of-indi.bio: Active leader in the Federation of Jewish Communities of India, working to coordinate activities among Bene Israel, Baghdadi, and Cochin Jewish communities.

federation-of-jewish-communities-of-indi.name: Benjamin Israel
federation-of-jewish-communities-of-indi.bio: Historian of Indian Jewry who served as an advisor to the Federation, contributing scholarly expertise on the community's history and heritage.

sassoon-docks.name: Albert Abdullah David Sassoon
sassoon-docks.bio: Son of David Sassoon who funded and oversaw the construction of the Sassoon Docks, Mumbai's oldest docks, completed in 1875.

sassoon-docks.name: Flora Sassoon
sassoon-docks.bio: Sassoon family matriarch who continued the family's extensive commercial and philanthropic presence in Mumbai, including the docks and other landmarks.

sassoon-docks.name: Rachel Sassoon Beer
sassoon-docks.bio: Sassoon descendant and groundbreaking newspaper editor who embodied the family's influential reach from Mumbai's docks to the British press.

chabad-mumbai-nariman-house.name: Rabbi Israel Kozlovsky
chabad-mumbai-nariman-house.bio: Leads the rebuilt Chabad House at Nariman House in Mumbai, continuing its mission as a center for Jewish travelers and local community members.

chabad-mumbai-nariman-house.name: Rivka Holtzberg
chabad-mumbai-nariman-house.bio: Co-directed Nariman House alongside her husband until both were murdered in the 2008 Mumbai terror attacks that targeted the Jewish center.

chabad-mumbai-nariman-house.name: Sandra Samuel
chabad-mumbai-nariman-house.bio: Indian nanny who saved baby Moshe Holtzberg during the 2008 attack on Nariman House, carrying him to safety under fire.

chabad-mumbai-nariman-house.name: Moshe Holtzberg
chabad-mumbai-nariman-house.bio: Orphaned son of the murdered Chabad directors who survived the 2008 Mumbai attacks as a toddler and has since revisited the rebuilt Nariman House.

reliance-industries.name: Dhirubhai Ambani
reliance-industries.bio: Founded Reliance Industries in 1966 as a small textiles firm in Mumbai, building it into India's largest private sector enterprise with interests in petrochemicals, energy, and telecom.

reliance-industries.name: Nita Ambani
reliance-industries.bio: Wife of Mukesh Ambani who leads the Reliance Foundation, overseeing the conglomerate's philanthropic, sports, and educational initiatives.

reliance-industries.name: Anil Ambani
reliance-industries.bio: Younger son of Dhirubhai Ambani who led the Reliance Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Group after the 2005 split of the family business empire.

cochin-jewish-heritage-centre.name: Sarah Cohen
cochin-jewish-heritage-centre.bio: One of the last Paradesi Jews of Kochi who became a beloved symbol of the Cochin Jewish community and its centuries-old heritage.

cochin-jewish-heritage-centre.name: Abraham Benedict Salem
cochin-jewish-heritage-centre.bio: Known as the 'Jewish Gandhi,' he was a prominent Cochin Jewish leader who fought for equality within the community and was an ardent Zionist.

cochin-jewish-heritage-centre.name: Essie Sassoon
cochin-jewish-heritage-centre.bio: Member of the Cochin Jewish community who has worked to preserve the heritage centre and its documentation of the community's centuries-long presence in Kerala.
